author: s1na
content: quick question: will `ShardState.data` be the root of the cross-linked object?

author: .vbuterin
content: I think `ShardState.data` is the "real" state root

author: .vbuterin
content: ie. not including the protocol-level auxiliary stuff

author: s1na
content: ah okay, so it's only the state root, it wouldn't include directly a reference to a receipt tree. i.e. for that we should use `ShardState.latest_block_root` and then reference it through the shard block header?

author: .vbuterin
content: aaah, sorry, it would include a receipt root too

author: s1na
content: another question i had was: let's say we want to prove a receipt from one shard to a second shard. is it okay to prove against the hash of an old beacon block? i.e can we expect people will store beacon blocks for some time, or we'll have to go through `BeaconState.state_roots` or `BeaconState.historical_roots` of a *very recent* block?

author: axic3354
content:
https://github.com/ethereum/eth2.0-specs/blob/dev/specs/phase1/beacon-chain.md#shardstate

<@!273808422753796097> in here you mean `data` is the real state root, while `latest_block_root` is some protocol wrapped version of the same?

It is a bit confusing to me, because the `apply_shard_transition` only cares about `latest_block_root`.

author: protolambda
content: The phase2 spec draft PR has some initial take on the use of the shard data roots and updating of phase1 code to do execution. Should be useful to you <@259648573401071617>

author: .vbuterin
content: > It is a bit confusing to me, because the apply_shard_transition only cares about latest_block_root.

author: .vbuterin
content: This is because the beacon chain code itself does not verify the shard transitions

author: .vbuterin
content: That's up to the committees and the fraud proof mechanism
